Frequently Asked Questions

1. What is the purpose of the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM)?
CBAM is designed to prevent carbon leakage — the relocation of carbon-intensive production outside the EU to countries with weaker climate rules. It ensures imported goods face a carbon cost similar to EU-made goods under the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS), supporting the EU’s targets of a 55% emissions reduction by 2030 and climate neutrality by 2050. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
2. How does CBAM work in practice?
Importers of covered goods must report the embedded emissions of those goods, and starting in 2026 they will need to purchase CBAM certificates. The price of these certificates mirrors the EU carbon price. If a producer has already paid a carbon price in the exporting country, that amount is deducted to avoid paying twice. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
3. What is the current phase of CBAM implementation?
CBAM entered its transitional phase on 1 October 2023. During this phase, importers submit quarterly emission reports but do not pay yet. The definitive phase begins in 2026, when payment through CBAM certificates starts. Policy updates in 2025 suggest the full obligation could be pushed toward 2027 and simplified for small importers. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
4. Which sectors and products are currently covered by CBAM?
CBAM currently applies to six high-emission areas: cement, iron and steel, aluminium, fertilisers, hydrogen, and electricity. These sectors were chosen due to their high carbon intensity and high risk of carbon leakage. The scope may later expand to downstream products such as fasteners, alloys, and recycled material streams. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
5. What do importers have to report during the transitional period?
Importers (or their indirect customs representatives) must submit quarterly reports describing: (a) how much of each CBAM good was imported, (b) the direct and indirect embedded emissions, and (c) any carbon price already paid in the country of origin. Reports are due one month after the end of each quarter. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
6. What reforms did the EU introduce in 2025?
The European Parliament backed several simplifications: a higher de minimis threshold of 50 tons/year (which could exempt around 90% of small importers by volume), permission to use default emission values, development of default country-level carbon price values, and the option to delay full CBAM rollout toward 2027. These changes aim to reduce burden on SMEs and improve fairness. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
7. How does CBAM affect developing and lower-income countries?
Low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) can be highly exposed because their economies often rely on CBAM sectors like cement and fertilisers, but they may lack the systems to measure and verify emissions. Small and medium suppliers in these countries risk being pushed out of EU value chains if they cannot provide compliant data. Some studies estimate income losses of up to 0.5% for certain African economies, which is why there are calls for EU technical and financial support. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
8. What happens to the money collected through CBAM?
CBAM is expected to generate around €2.1 billion per year. While these funds currently feed mainly into the EU budget, many experts argue that a portion should support international climate finance — for example, helping exporting countries invest in cleaner industrial processes and measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV) systems. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
9. Are there penalties for not complying with CBAM reporting?
Yes. During the transitional phase, failing to report embedded emissions — or submitting incomplete or incorrect data and not correcting it — can lead to penalties of €10 to €50 per tonne of unreported emissions. National competent authorities are responsible for enforcement and may require corrections before issuing fines. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
10. How is the EU trying to make CBAM fairer globally?
The EU’s policy discussions highlight five priorities: (1) simplify compliance for SMEs and developing countries, (2) extend CBAM to more products to avoid loopholes, (3) fund technical and financial support so exporting countries can measure and cut emissions, (4) recognize equivalent foreign carbon pricing or verified green investments, and (5) dedicate part of CBAM revenues to global decarbonization. The goal is to align climate ambition with fairness. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
